newsitem.title: UK: Eurotunnel less hopeful on tunnel opening - agency.
newsitem.headline: Eurotunnel less hopeful on tunnel opening - agency.

text.p: Eurotunnel Plc said on Tuesday fire damage to the tunnel was worse than first thought but the channel tunnel operator still hopes to run a service on Wednesday, the Press Association news agency reported.

"There is a lot of mess down there. Our people will be working throughout the night but I think we have to be less optimistic than we were earlier," said Eurotunnel operations director, Alain Bertrand. "Clearly there is more to do to restore services and equipment which were damaged by the fire."

Hopes had been high earlier on Tuesday that the undamaged Channel tunnel railtrack would begin a partial service on Wednesday morning but Bertrand said some travellers may be allowed through on Wednesday afternoon "at the very earliest".

Senior Eurotunnel staff, including president Patrick Ponsolle, went into the tunnel to see at first hand the havoc caused by a fire in a lorry which shut down the Channel Tunnel for the first time since operations began in 1994.
Bertrand said one of the main lines of inquiry would be a suggestion that one lorry's cargo was already smouldering before the freight train entered the tunnel at Calais.
"We are looking into that. It may be there were the beginnings of a fire early on which our fire alarms did not detect," he said.
"It might have been that it did not become a big fire until the train was inside the tunnel."
